etymology.description: 人(人) (rén, "person") + 卩(卩) (jié, "seal") = person with seal -> issuing orders or commands
etymology.interpretation: The character 令(令) (lǐng, "order") combines 人(人) (rén, "person") and 卩(卩) (jié, "seal") to depict someone with a seal or authority, signifying the power to issue orders or commands.

examples.chinese: 将军令部队保持警戒(將軍令部隊保持警戒)，士兵严格服从(士兵嚴格服從)。
examples.pinyin: jiāngjūn lǐng bùduì bǎochí jǐngjiè, shìbīng yángé fúcóng.
examples.english: The general orders the troops to maintain vigilance, and the soldiers strictly obey.

examples.chinese: 老师令学生认真听讲(老師令學生認真聽講)。
examples.english: The teacher orders the students to listen attentively.

examples.chinese: 国王令大臣速速筹备(國王令大臣速速籌備)，迎接远方使节(迎接遠方使節)。
examples.pinyin: guówáng lǐng dàchén sùsù chóubèi, yíngjiē yuǎnfāng shǐjié.
examples.english: The king orders his ministers to quickly make preparations to welcome the foreign envoy.
